user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_timeout_millisec_:
```c
static int64_t
get_timeout_millisec_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                       int32_t max_timeout)
{
  uint64_t d_timeout;
  mhd_assert (0 <= max_timeout || -1 == max_timeout);
  if (0 == max_timeout)
    return 0;

  if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &d_timeout))
    return max_timeout;

  if ((0 < max_timeout) && ((uint64_t) max_timeout < d_timeout))
    return max_timeout;

  if (INT64_MAX <= d_timeout)
    return INT64_MAX;

  return (int64_t) d_timeout;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 21.14 prohibits using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. I inspected the provided function get_timeout_millisec_. It contains only integer types, integer comparisons, a cast, returns, an assertion, and a call to MHD_get_timeout64. There are no uses of memcmp, no other memory-compare functions (memcmp-like), and no operations on char* or null-terminated strings (no strcmp/strncmp/strcpy/etc.). Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for Rule 21.14. Note: the call to MHD_get_timeout64 is external to this fragment and does not appear in the provided code; if that external function used memcmp on null-terminated strings it would need review, but it is not present here and thus not included as a suspicious fragment.
